description: c. 1350–1400, Middle English clokke, clok, cloke, from Middle Dutch clocke (“bell, clock”), from Old Dutch *klokka, from Medieval Latin clocca, probably of Celtic origin, from Proto-Celtic *klokkos (“bell”) (compare Welsh cloch, Old Irish cloc), either onomatopoeic or from Proto-Indo-European *klek- (“to laugh, cackle”) (compare Proto-Germanic *hlahjaną (“to laugh”)).
Related to Old English clucge, Saterland Frisian Klokke (“bell; clock”), Low German Klock (“bell, clock”), German Glocke, Swedish klocka.

entries.meaning: An instrument that measures or keeps track of time; a non-wearable timepiece.
(attributive) A common noun relating to an instrument that measures or keeps track of time.
examples: A 12-hour clock system; an antique clock sale; Acme is a clock manufacturer.

entries.meaning: (Britain) The odometer of a motor vehicle.
examples: This car has over 300,000 miles on the clock.

entries.meaning: (electronics) An electrical signal that synchronizes timing among digital circuits of semiconductor chips or modules.
The seed head of a dandelion.

examples: I can't go off to lunch yet: I'm still on the clock.
We let the guys use the shop's tools and equipment for their own projects as long as they're off the clock.

entries.meaning: (computing, informal) A CPU clock cycle, or T-state.
examples: Executing a NEXT to code takes 7 clocks, or 1.05 microseconds.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A luck-based patience or solitaire card game with the cards laid out to represent the face of a clock.

verbs.description: clock (third-person singular simple present clocks, present participle clocking, simple past and past participle clocked)

examples: He was clocked at 155 miles per hour.
When the boxer let down his guard, his opponent clocked him.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive, slang) To take notice of; to realise; to recognize (someone or something).

entries.meaning: (transgender slang) To identify (someone) as being transgender.
examples: A trans person may be able to easily clock other trans people.

entries.meaning: (Britain, slang) To falsify the reading of the odometer of a vehicle.
examples: I don't believe that car has done only 40,000 miles. It's been clocked.
Synonyms: turn back (the vehicle's) clock, wind back (the vehicle's) clock

entries.meaning: (transitive, Britain, New Zealand, slang) To beat a video game.
examples: Have you clocked that game yet?

description: Uncertain; designs may have originally been bell-shaped and thus related to Etymology 1, above.

entries.meaning: A pattern near the heel of a sock or stocking.
examples: his stockings with silver clocks were ravished from him

verbs.description: clock (third-person singular simple present clocks, present participle clocking, simple past and past participle clocked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To ornament (e.g. the side of a stocking) with figured work.
A large beetle, especially the European dung beetle (Geotrupes stercorarius).

description: Old English cloccian ultimately imitative; compare Dutch klokken, English cluck.

verbs.description: clock (third-person singular simple present clocks, present participle clocking, simple past and past participle clocked)

entries.meaning: (Scotland, intransitive, dated) To make the sound of a hen; to cluck.
